reviewText:
Have you ever played a Worms title and wondered what it would be like to have infinite ninja rope and no time limit? Or maybe you just dream of being Spider-Man and think that superheroes who fly are just cheating. If neither of those applies to you but you want a zen-like platforming (as far as platforming is involved because the game features platforms to avoid rather than traverse) experience that isn't loaded with spikes, traps, and pitfalls, this is the game for you too.

The graphics and presentation are minimalistic and sublime, the soundtrack is soothing, and the gameplay itself is simple. It runs smoothly, making those moments when you hit top speed feel ever so good and your graceful arcs that take you above and below the water's surface show that physics simulations need not be infinitely complex.

I personally find it less a 'game' and more a relaxing experience that brings a calm smile, reminding me of games like Flower. And for the price tag, you don't have anything to lose.

Ninja Rope Simulator 2014 gets a 10/10 red dots from me.

This is one of those games where I'm left speechless. The game is free, and it's only an 11MB download, which means you could have finished downloading it by the time you've finished reading this review.

The game presents itself in such a way you don't want to let go. You're this Spiderman-esque dot, swinging around by clicking in the direction of different blocks, throwing yourself into these lines. Once you go through them, it adds to your points score which offers no reward in itself, other than some sort of milky satisfaction for completionists.

It's hard to criticise a game that presents itself so lovely, and the fact it's free makes it hard to refuse. But unlike, for example Angry Birds, there is no sense of progression, and can get bored very quickly. Each level you move on to is just random block placement. I believe that lack of goal is what makes Floating Point what it is - it doesn't dress itself up, and there's no penalty for whatever.

It's a lovely game, but it personally isn't for me. It is very peaceful and relaxing, which some may find as a stress relief - which I imagine makes this someone's perfect cup of tea. Sadly, I prefer coffee. But I find myself firing this up now and then for some relaxation, and Floating Point works a treat.

It's a fun little game where you shoot a grappling hook at blocks and swing between other blocks to collect red beacons.
Each level is identicle in it's aesthetic and objectives and offers no variation. There isn't much to it. But what there is, it does really well.

The swinging is responsive and if you practice enough, allows you to completely avoid every obsticle, giving you maximum points. There are 2 areas, air and water. In the air, gravity pulls you down. In the water, buoyancy pushes you up. This forces you to be able to switch your swinging techniques as you fling yourself between the 2.

This game rewards good players. The beacons that must be collected grow when you move quickly without hitting obsticles, and shrink when you crash or slow down. This means that if you're not good at the game, the game becomes more difficult just to rub it in. This, however, is not a criticism. Too many games are letting the bad player get off too easy these days.

That said, this game is not challenging. Then again, it's not supposed to be. As is written above in the About the Game" section

Floating Point is a very interesting game in concept and gameplay. You take control of a small red dot with the ability to swing around. Your goal is to reach red bars that add to your score. They grow taller as you increase your momentum via swinging. The game is centered around the concept of grace, and this is reflected by a silhouette of your movements at the end of the level.
Things I liked:
Serene atmosphere and music.
Original concept with the gravity switching between halves of the level.
Easy to pick up and play. Sometimes simplicity is best.
Free and small.
Music changes as you enter the other half of the level. Bonus points for not fading the music until you can't hear it like Sonic Generations.Things I did not like:
The inherent lightness and floaty qualities of the dot made control somewhat difficult. I understand that this is so momentum can be built faster, but sometimes this can be hindering.
While the small size is also a plus, it is indeed a downside. This game gets old very quickly, but this is to be expected from something free.All in all, Floating Point is a good game to try. I just don't understand why so many people are giving it a perfect ten. This game is not without it's flaws. But I do want to give it a higher rating than IGN gave Shrek Superslam.

reviewText: This is a neat little game. After jumping in, the concept may take some getting used to -- but, once you get the hang of it, your actions feel much less random and pointless (something like button-mashing), and once you get good at it, it's anything but boring.\n\nSooner or later you'll figure out how the scoring system works, and you'll really be pushing to beat your high score which can be especially frustrating with how slow the ball moves. However, that doesn't matter, because this game offers settings that allow you to change the values of the game properties (the strengths of retraction, block density, etc.). If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText:
This one's okay, but it's not the kind of game you'd spend hours playing. I mean, it's a bit interesting to play, but not really fun enough for a hardcore gamer such as myself. This one's for the casuals out there.

When you start off the game, you're greeted to the controls. Nice and simple. As stated in the system requirements you really can't even try to play this without a real mouse. Then, you're off. Obviously, this is one of those physics games without any real theme or setting, so don't expect any of that. Now, here's the best part of the game: you get to fling your little dot around the rectanges and collect the little squares (that extend into collumns when you're going fast).
Sounds fun, right?

Right?

Yeah, it is, but the game tends to get quite boring once you've been playing for a few minutes or so.
It's a nice idea, but I'm not sure if Steam was the right place for it. This feels like something that should I should be playing on my Android phone as opposed to on my laptop.
And, I know it sounds like I'm just plain out complaining, but the music kinda doesn't fit with the theme. It's great, but really doesn't belong with the game.

This one's kinda stuck in the middle for me. Likewise, it gets a lukewarm 3/5 stars.

When I first started Floating Point up, I was immediately lost and frustrated as I kept hitting walls, unable to speed up at all, and there was no incentive to spend time getting better at it. The controls are counterintuitive and don't take advantage of the natural human perception of momentum and centrifugal force. It seems like a nice concept that wasn't translated effectively for the casual gamer.\n\nThere are other games that have a more effective swinging mechanic, such as Aether, which throws a storyline integrated with the mechanics and an immersive art style into the mix, being free in addition. Floating Point isn't really worth playing in light of those. It may be more polished both visually and aurally, but when it comes down to actual gameplay it's more of a struggle than a relaxing pastime.

First off, Floating Point has no story,  but it doesn't need one, because it wants to be a physics game that just wants to be fun and entertaining, During my short play of the game, I had a lot of fun with it, on default settings alone, but then I started playing with the customization and learned what you could do with the game, and unleash its true potential.

You can adjust everything about the game, the speed, the bars, even the height required to have the nice music and pretty lighting. You can even make it to where you get over flowed points that was probably added in because I didn't crash when I broke the game, there's no bugs or anything, and every computer can play this game. There's no reason why EVERYONE shouldn't at least try the game out, if the default settings are boring, then go ahead and break the game.

It can even be used as a teaching tool to teach momentum and physics, seeing as how its a PHYSICS game in the first place.

In short, I give this game a 10 out of 10 for being shockingly addicting.

Floating Point is a fun and relaxing game from the maker of Gunpoint. It's a 2D game in which you shoot a grappling hook and collect the bars that are dotted around the level. The more momentum you gain, the longer the bars become and more points you earn. The levels are generated procedurally and get progressively harder with more platforms at greater height and depth. The trick is to shoot your hook in such a way that you keep up the momentum while trying to get as many bars as possible in one swing. All that without accidentally hitting a platform and loosing momentum. Definitely worth a spin. And it's free too!

Floating Point is a simple little game (which was created by the same person who made Gunpoint, which is also incredible) where you control a ball and have to swing from block to block to pick up bars and rack up points. The way you swing around is pretty similar to the Spider-Man 2 game- you connect to a block and you swing around it, and your rope wraps around any blocks it hits. It's pretty cool when you can get a lot of speed up and get more points. The controls are simple: left click to connect with a block, hold left click to reel yourself in, and right click to let go.

The music isn't anything spectacular but it fits well with the game.

Overall, Floating Point is a nice game to get if you want something to play to kill some time. The file size is really small so it will only take a minute or so to download. Plus it's FREE. Very unique and very fun.
